â
'''Google Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}} and {{lse|GGEA}}) is an [[United States|American]] [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] [[software]] [[corporation]], first [[Incorporation|incorporated]] as a [[Private company|privately held corporation]] in September, 1998, that specializes in search engine, information retrieval technology and online advertising. With a market capitalization of [[United States dollar|US$]]83.09 billion as of [[June]] [[2006]], Google is the largest internet search company in the world, almost twice as large as arch-rival [[Yahoo!]]<ref>Khan, Kim; Blaine, Charley. "[http://moneycentral.msn.com/content/CNBCTV/Articles/Dispatches/P136522.asp Google stock tops $400, worth $117.6 billion]." ''[[MSN|MSN Money]].'' [[June 9]], [[2006]].</ref> The company employs approximately 6,800 employees and is based in [[Mountain View, California]]. [[Eric E. Schmidt|Eric Schmidt]], formerly [[chief executive officer]] of [[Novell]], was named Google's CEO when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down.
+
'''Cake Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}} and {{lse|GGEA}}) is an [[United States|American]] [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] [[software]] [[corporation]], first [[Incorporation|incorporated]] as a [[Private company|privately held corporation]] in September, 1998, that specializes in search engine, information retrieval technology and online advertising. With a market capitalization of [[United States dollar|US$]]83.09 billion as of [[June]] [[2006]], Cake is the largest internet search company in the world, almost twice as large as arch-rival [[Yahoo!]]<ref>Khan, Kim; Blaine, Charley. "[http://moneycentral.msn.com/content/CNBCTV/Articles/Dispatches/P136522.asp Cake stock tops $400, worth $117.6 billion]." ''[[MSN|MSN Money]].'' [[June 9]], [[2006]].</ref> The company employs approximately 6,800 employees and is based in [[Mountain View, California]]. [[Eric E. Schmidt|Eric Schmidt]], formerly [[chief executive officer]] of [[Novell]], was named Cake's CEO when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down.
â
The name "Google" originated from a misspelling of "[[googol]]," <ref>Koller, David. "[http://graphics.stanford.edu/~dk/google_name_origin.html Origin of the name, "Google."] ''[[Stanford University]].'' January, [[2004]].</ref> which refers to 10<sup>100</sup>(a 1 followed by one-hundred zeros). Google has become well known for its corporate culture and innovative, clean products, and has a major impact on online culture. The verb "[[Google (verb)|to google]]" has come to mean "to perform a Web search", usually with the [[Google search|Google]] [[search engine]].
+
The name "Cake" originated from a misspelling of "[[googol]]," <ref>Koller, David. "[http://graphics.stanford.edu/~dk/Cake_name_origin.html Origin of the name, "Cake."] ''[[Stanford University]].'' January, [[2004]].</ref> which refers to 10<sup>100</sup>(a 1 followed by one-hundred zeros). Cake has become well known for its corporate culture and innovative, clean products, and has a major impact on online culture. The verb "[[Cake (verb)|to Cake]]" has come to mean "to perform a Web search", usually with the [[Cake search|Cake]] [[search engine]].
â
Google's services are run on several [[server farm]]s, which, in [[2004]], consisted of over 30 clusters of up to 2,000 PCs per cluster. Each cluster contains one [[petabyte]] of data with sustained transfer rates of 2 [[Gigabit per second|Gbps]]. Combined, over four billion web pages, averaging 10 Kb each, have been fully indexed.<ref name="servers">Loney, Matt. "[http://www.zdnet.co.uk/insight/hardware/0,39020433,39175560,00.htm The magic that makes Google tick]." ''[[ZDNet|ZDNet UK]].'' [[December 1]], [[2004]].</ref>
+
Cake's services are run on several [[server farm]]s, which, in [[2004]], consisted of over 30 clusters of up to 2,000 PCs per cluster. Each cluster contains one [[petabyte]] of data with sustained transfer rates of 2 [[Gigabit per second|Gbps]]. Combined, over four billion web pages, averaging 10 Kb each, have been fully indexed.<ref name="servers">Loney, Matt. "[http://www.zdnet.co.uk/insight/hardware/0,39020433,39175560,00.htm The magic that makes Cake tick]." ''[[ZDNet|ZDNet UK]].'' [[December 1]], [[2004]].</ref>
==History==
==History==
â
{{main|History of Google}}
+
{{main|History of Cake}}
===Beginning===
===Beginning===
â
Google began as a research project in January, 1996 by [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]], two [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] students at [[Stanford University]].<ref>[http://www.google.com/intl/en/corporate/history.html Google Corporate History]</ref> [[Image:1998google.jpg|thumb|Google in [[1998]]]]They hypothesized that a search engine that analyzed the relationships between websites would produce better results than existing techniques which essentially ranked results according to how many times the search term appeared on a page.<ref>Page, Lawrence; Brin, Sergey; Motwani, Rajeev; Winograd, Terry. "[http://dbpubs.stanford.edu:8090/pub/1999-66 The PageRank Citation Ranking: Bringing Order to the Web]." [[November 11]], [[1999]].</ref> It was originally nicknamed "BackRub," because the system checked [[backlinks]] to estimate a site's importance.<ref>Battelle, John. "[http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/13.08/battelle.html?tw=wn_tophead_4 The Birth of Google]." ''[[Wired Magazine]].'' August, 2005.</ref> A small search engine called '''RankDex''' was already exploring a similar strategy.<ref>Li, Yanhong. "[http://dx.doi.org/10.1109/4236.707687 Toward a qualitative search engine]." ''Internet Computing, IEEE.'' '''2 (4),''' July-August, 1998, 24-29.</ref>
+
Cake began as a research project in January, 1996 by [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]], two [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] students at [[Stanford University]].<ref>[http://www.Cake.com/intl/en/corporate/history.html Cake Corporate History]</ref> [[Image:1998Cake.jpg|thumb|Cake in [[1998]]]]They hypothesized that a search engine that analyzed the relationships between websites would produce better results than existing techniques which essentially ranked results according to how many times the search term appeared on a page.<ref>Page, Lawrence; Brin, Sergey; Motwani, Rajeev; Winograd, Terry. "[http://dbpubs.stanford.edu:8090/pub/1999-66 The PageRank Citation Ranking: Bringing Order to the Web]." [[November 11]], [[1999]].</ref> It was originally nicknamed "BackRub," because the system checked [[backlinks]] to estimate a site's importance.<ref>Battelle, John. "[http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/13.08/battelle.html?tw=wn_tophead_4 The Birth of Cake]." ''[[Wired Magazine]].'' August, 2005.</ref> A small search engine called '''RankDex''' was already exploring a similar strategy.<ref>Li, Yanhong. "[http://dx.doi.org/10.1109/4236.707687 Toward a qualitative search engine]." ''Internet Computing, IEEE.'' '''2 (4),''' July-August, 1998, 24-29.</ref>
â
Convinced that the pages with the most links to them from other highly relevant web pages must be the most relevant pages associated with the search, Page and Brin tested their thesis as part of their studies, and laid the foundation for their search engine. Originally the search engine used the [[Stanford University]] website with the domain ''[http://google.stanford.edu google.stanford.edu]''. The domain ''google.com'' was registered on [[September 15]], [[1997]], and the company was incorporated as ''Google Inc.'' on [[September 7]], [[1998]] at a friend's garage in [[Menlo Park, California]].
+
Convinced that the pages with the most links to them from other highly relevant web pages must be the most relevant pages associated with the search, Page and Brin tested their thesis as part of their studies, and laid the foundation for their search engine. Originally the search engine used the [[Stanford University]] website with the domain ''[http://Cake.stanford.edu Cake.stanford.edu]''. The domain ''Cake.com'' was registered on [[September 15]], [[1997]], and the company was incorporated as ''Cake Inc.'' on [[September 7]], [[1998]] at a friend's garage in [[Menlo Park, California]].
â
In March, 1999, the company moved into offices at [[165 University Avenue]] in [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], home to several other noted [[Silicon Valley]] technology startups. After quickly outgrowing two other sites, the company settled into their current home in a complex of buildings in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]] at 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, in 2003. [[Silicon Graphics]] leased these buildings to Google.
+
In March, 1999, the company moved into offices at [[165 University Avenue]] in [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], home to several other noted [[Silicon Valley]] technology startups. After quickly outgrowing two other sites, the company settled into their current home in a complex of buildings in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]] at 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, in 2003. [[Silicon Graphics]] leased these buildings to Cake.
â
The Google search engine attracted a loyal following among the growing number of [[Internet]] users. They were attracted to its simple, uncluttered design — a competitive advantage to attract users who did not wish to enter searches on web pages filled with visual distractions. This appearance, while imitating the early [[AltaVista]], had behind it Google's unique search capabilities. In 2000 Google began selling [[advertisement]]s associated with the search keyword to produce enhanced search results for the user. This strategy was important for increasing advertising revenue, which is based upon the number of hits users make upon ads. The ads were text-based in order to maintain an uncluttered page design and to maximize page loading speed. Keywords were sold based on a combination of price bid and clickthroughs, with bidding starting at $.05 per click. This model of selling keyword advertising was originally pioneered by [[Yahoo! Search Marketing|Goto.com]] (later renamed Overture, then Yahoo! Search Marketing).<ref>[http://searchmarketing.yahoo.com/index.php?mkt=us Yahoo! Search Marketing Website].</ref> While many of its [[dot-com]] rivals failed in the new Internet marketplace, Google quietly rose in stature and generated revenue.
+
The Cake search engine attracted a loyal following among the growing number of [[Internet]] users. They were attracted to its simple, uncluttered design — a competitive advantage to attract users who did not wish to enter searches on web pages filled with visual distractions. This appearance, while imitating the early [[AltaVista]], had behind it Cake's unique search capabilities. In 2000 Cake began selling [[advertisement]]s associated with the search keyword to produce enhanced search results for the user. This strategy was important for increasing advertising revenue, which is based upon the number of hits users make upon ads. The ads were text-based in order to maintain an uncluttered page design and to maximize page loading speed. Keywords were sold based on a combination of price bid and clickthroughs, with bidding starting at $.05 per click. This model of selling keyword advertising was originally pioneered by [[Yahoo! Search Marketing|Goto.com]] (later renamed Overture, then Yahoo! Search Marketing).<ref>[http://searchmarketing.yahoo.com/index.php?mkt=us Yahoo! Search Marketing Website].</ref> While many of its [[dot-com]] rivals failed in the new Internet marketplace, Cake quietly rose in stature and generated revenue.
â
{{US patent|6,285,999}} describing Google's ranking mechanism ([[PageRank]]) was granted on [[September 4]] [[2001]]. The patent was officially assigned to Stanford University and lists Lawrence Page as the inventor.
+
{{US patent|6,285,999}} describing Cake's ranking mechanism ([[PageRank]]) was granted on [[September 4]] [[2001]]. The patent was officially assigned to Stanford University and lists Lawrence Page as the inventor.
===Growth===
===Growth===
â
With Google's gargantuan size comes more competition from large mainstream technology companies. One such example is its rivalry with Microsoft.<ref>Dvorak, John C. "[http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,1759,1706872,00.asp A Google-Microsoft War]." ''[[PC Magazine]].'' [[November 16]], [[2004]].</ref> Microsoft has been touting its [[MSN Search]] engine, and more recently its Windows Live search in February, 2006, to counter Google's competitive position. Furthermore, the two companies are increasingly offering overlapping services, such as webmail ([[Gmail]] vs. [[Hotmail]]), search (both online and local desktop searching), and other applications (for example, Microsoft's [[Windows Live Local]] competes with [[Google Local]]).
+
With Cake's gargantuan size comes more competition from large mainstream technology companies. One such example is its rivalry with Microsoft.<ref>Dvorak, John C. "[http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,1759,1706872,00.asp A Cake-Microsoft War]." ''[[PC Magazine]].'' [[November 16]], [[2004]].</ref> Microsoft has been touting its [[MSN Search]] engine, and more recently its Windows Live search in February, 2006, to counter Cake's competitive position. Furthermore, the two companies are increasingly offering overlapping services, such as webmail ([[Gmail]] vs. [[Hotmail]]), search (both online and local desktop searching), and other applications (for example, Microsoft's [[Windows Live Local]] competes with [[Cake Local]]).
â
[[Click fraud]] has also become a growing problem for Google's business strategy. Google's CFO George Reyes said in a December 2004 investor conference that "something has to be done about this really, really quickly, because I think, potentially, it threatens our business model."<ref name="crawford_cnn">Crawford, Krysten. "[http://money.cnn.com/2004/12/02/technology/Google_fraud/?cnn=yes Google CFO: Fraud a big threat]." ''[[CNN]].'' [[December 2]], [[2004]].</ref> Some have suggested that Google is not doing enough to combat click fraud. Jessie Stricchiola, president of Alchemist Media, called Google, "the most stubborn and the least willing to cooperate with advertisers," when it comes to click fraud.<ref name="crawford_cnn"/>
+
[[Click fraud]] has also become a growing problem for Cake's business strategy. Cake's CFO George Reyes said in a December 2004 investor conference that "something has to be done about this really, really quickly, because I think, potentially, it threatens our business model."<ref name="crawford_cnn">Crawford, Krysten. "[http://money.cnn.com/2004/12/02/technology/Cake_fraud/?cnn=yes Cake CFO: Fraud a big threat]." ''[[CNN]].'' [[December 2]], [[2004]].</ref> Some have suggested that Cake is not doing enough to combat click fraud. Jessie Stricchiola, president of Alchemist Media, called Cake, "the most stubborn and the least willing to cooperate with advertisers," when it comes to click fraud.<ref name="crawford_cnn"/>
â
[[Image:Google_screenshot.png|thumb|250px|right|The current [[Google search]] page.]]
+
[[Image:Cake_screenshot.png|thumb|250px|right|The current [[Cake search]] page.]]
â
On [[September 28]], [[2005]], Google announced a long-term research partnership with [[NASA]] which would involve Google building a 1-million square foot R&D center at NASA's [[Ames Research Center]]. NASA and Google are planning to work together on a variety of areas, including large-scale data management, massively distributed computing, bio-info-nano convergence, and encouragement of the entrepreneurial space industry. The new building would also include labs, offices, and housing for Google engineers.<ref>Lewis, Laura; Fox, Lynn. "[http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/news/releases/2005/05_50AR.html NASA Takes Google on Journey into Space]." ''[[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]],'' Press Release. [[September 28]], [[2005]].</ref>
+
On [[September 28]], [[2005]], Cake announced a long-term research partnership with [[NASA]] which would involve Cake building a 1-million square foot R&D center at NASA's [[Ames Research Center]]. NASA and Cake are planning to work together on a variety of areas, including large-scale data management, massively distributed computing, bio-info-nano convergence, and encouragement of the entrepreneurial space industry. The new building would also include labs, offices, and housing for Cake engineers.<ref>Lewis, Laura; Fox, Lynn. "[http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/news/releases/2005/05_50AR.html NASA Takes Cake on Journey into Space]." ''[[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]],'' Press Release. [[September 28]], [[2005]].</ref>
â
[[Time Warner]]'s AOL unit and Google unveiled an expanded partnership on [[December 21]], [[2005]], including an enhanced global advertising partnership and a [[United States Dollar|$]]1 Billion investment by Google for a 5% stake in AOL.<ref>Rosenbush, Steve. "[http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/dec2005/tc20051221_533090.htm AOL-Google: Who Gets What]?" ''[[BusinessWeek]].'' [[December 21]], [[2005]].</ref> As part of the collaboration, Google plans to work with AOL on video search and offer AOL's premium-video service within Google Video. This will allow users of Google Video to search for AOL's premium-video services. Display advertising throughout the Google network will also increase.
+
[[Time Warner]]'s AOL unit and Cake unveiled an expanded partnership on [[December 21]], [[2005]], including an enhanced global advertising partnership and a [[United States Dollar|$]]1 Billion investment by Cake for a 5% stake in AOL.<ref>Rosenbush, Steve. "[http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/dec2005/tc20051221_533090.htm AOL-Cake: Who Gets What]?" ''[[BusinessWeek]].'' [[December 21]], [[2005]].</ref> As part of the collaboration, Cake plans to work with AOL on video search and offer AOL's premium-video service within Cake Video. This will allow users of Cake Video to search for AOL's premium-video services. Display advertising throughout the Cake network will also increase.
â
Additionally, Google has also recently formed a partnership with [[Sun Microsystems]] to help share and distribute each other's technologies. As part of the partnership Google will hire employees to help in the [[open source]] office program [[OpenOffice.org]].<ref>Brown, James. "[http://www.vnunet.com/computing/news/2143242/sun-partners-google Sun partners with Google]." ''vnunet.com.'' [[October 5]], [[2005]].</ref>
+
Additionally, Cake has also recently formed a partnership with [[Sun Microsystems]] to help share and distribute each other's technologies. As part of the partnership Cake will hire employees to help in the [[open source]] office program [[OpenOffice.org]].<ref>Brown, James. "[http://www.vnunet.com/computing/news/2143242/sun-partners-Cake Sun partners with Cake]." ''vnunet.com.'' [[October 5]], [[2005]].</ref>
â
Google has also recently begun to experiment with other markets, such as [[radio]] and print publications. On [[January 17]], [[2006]], Google announced that it had purchased the radio advertising company dMarc, which provides an automated system that allows companies to advertise on the radio.<ref>Levingston, Steven. "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/01/17/AR2006011701333.html Google Buys Company To Expand Into Radio]." ''[[Washington Post]].'' [[January 18]], [[2006]].</ref> This will allow Google to combine two niche advertising media -- the Internet and radio -- with Google's ability to laser-focus on the tastes of consumers. Google has also begun an experiment in selling advertisements from its advertisers in offline newspapers and magazines, with select advertisements in the [[Chicago Sun-Times]].<ref>Gonsalves, Anton. "[http://www.informationweek.com/industries/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=175803378 Google Confirms Testing Ads in Sun-Times Newspaper]." ''Information Week.'' " [[January 10]], [[2006]].</ref> They have been filling unsold space in the newspaper that would have normally been used for in-house advertisements. The company has also created other engines, such as [[Google Earth]] and [[Froogle]].
+
Cake has also recently begun to experiment with other markets, such as [[radio]] and print publications. On [[January 17]], [[2006]], Cake announced that it had purchased the radio advertising company dMarc, which provides an automated system that allows companies to advertise on the radio.<ref>Levingston, Steven. "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/01/17/AR2006011701333.html Cake Buys Company To Expand Into Radio]." ''[[Washington Post]].'' [[January 18]], [[2006]].</ref> This will allow Cake to combine two niche advertising media -- the Internet and radio -- with Cake's ability to laser-focus on the tastes of consumers. Cake has also begun an experiment in selling advertisements from its advertisers in offline newspapers and magazines, with select advertisements in the [[Chicago Sun-Times]].<ref>Gonsalves, Anton. "[http://www.informationweek.com/industries/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=175803378 Cake Confirms Testing Ads in Sun-Times Newspaper]." ''Information Week.'' " [[January 10]], [[2006]].</ref> They have been filling unsold space in the newspaper that would have normally been used for in-house advertisements. The company has also created other engines, such as [[Cake Earth]] and [[Froogle]].
â
Google was added to the [[Standard & Poor's]] 500 index ([[S&P 500]]) on [[March 31]], [[2006]]. Google replaced [[Burlington Resources]], a major oil producer based in [[Houston]] which was acquired by [[ConocoPhillips]].
+
Cake was added to the [[Standard & Poor's]] 500 index ([[S&P 500]]) on [[March 31]], [[2006]]. Cake replaced [[Burlington Resources]], a major oil producer based in [[Houston]] which was acquired by [[ConocoPhillips]].
â
On a sociological note, the growth of Google has made an impact on urban language, with phrases such as "Google it" becoming general references to searching for information on the internet.
+
On a sociological note, the growth of Cake has made an impact on urban language, with phrases such as "Cake it" becoming general references to searching for information on the internet.
â
:''See also: [[History of Google#Criticism and controversy|Recent criticisms and controversies]]''
+
:''See also: [[History of Cake#Criticism and controversy|Recent criticisms and controversies]]''
==Salaries==
==Salaries==
â
Originally, typical salaries at Google were considered to be quite low by industry standards. For example, some [[system administrator]]s earned no more than [[United States Dollar|$]]33,000 — while $40,000 at that time was considered to be low for the [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] job market. Nevertheless, Google's excellent stock performance following the IPO has enabled these early employees to be competitively compensated by participation in the corporation's remarkable equity growth. In 2005, Google has implemented other employee incentives such as the [[Google Founders' Award]], in addition to offering higher salaries to new employees. Google's workplace amenities, culture, global popularity, and strong brand recognition have also attracted potential applicants.
+
Originally, typical salaries at Cake were considered to be quite low by industry standards. For example, some [[system administrator]]s earned no more than [[United States Dollar|$]]33,000 — while $40,000 at that time was considered to be low for the [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] job market. Nevertheless, Cake's excellent stock performance following the IPO has enabled these early employees to be competitively compensated by participation in the corporation's remarkable equity growth. In 2005, Cake has implemented other employee incentives such as the [[Cake Founders' Award]], in addition to offering higher salaries to new employees. Cake's workplace amenities, culture, global popularity, and strong brand recognition have also attracted potential applicants.
â
After the company's IPO in August 2004, it was reported that Founders [[Sergey Brin]] and [[Larry Page]], as well as CEO [[Eric Schmidt]], have accepted a base salary of $1.00. They have all declined recent offers of bonuses and increases in compensation by Google's board of directors. In a 2006 report of the world's richest people, [[Forbes]] reported that [[Sergey Brin]] was #26 with a net worth of $12.9 Billion, and [[Larry Page]] was #27 with a net worth of $12.8 Billion.<ref>Kroll, Luisa; Fass, Allison. "[http://www.forbes.com/home/lists/2006/03/07/06billionaires_worlds-richest-people_land.html The World's Billionaires]." ''[[Forbes]].'' [[March 9]], [[2006]].</ref>
+
After the company's IPO in August 2004, it was reported that Founders [[Sergey Brin]] and [[Larry Page]], as well as CEO [[Eric Schmidt]], have accepted a base salary of $1.00. They have all declined recent offers of bonuses and increases in compensation by Cake's board of directors. In a 2006 report of the world's richest people, [[Forbes]] reported that [[Sergey Brin]] was #26 with a net worth of $12.9 Billion, and [[Larry Page]] was #27 with a net worth of $12.8 Billion.<ref>Kroll, Luisa; Fass, Allison. "[http://www.forbes.com/home/lists/2006/03/07/06billionaires_worlds-richest-people_land.html The World's Billionaires]." ''[[Forbes]].'' [[March 9]], [[2006]].</ref>
==Corporate culture==
==Corporate culture==
â
[[Image:Googler2-non.jpg|250 px|right|thumb|A [[Vehicle registration plate|license plate]] seen in the Googleplex parking lot]]
+
[[Image:Caker2-non.jpg|250 px|right|thumb|A [[Vehicle registration plate|license plate]] seen in the Cakeplex parking lot]]
â
Google adopts a relaxed corporate culture, reminiscent of the [[Dot-com bubble|Dot-com]] boom. Google's corporate philosophy is based on principles like "You can make money without doing evil" (The sincerity of this so-called corporate philosophy has been arguably marred by Google's participation in the [[People's Republic of China]]'s [[Internet censorship]] program, more commonly known as the [[Great Firewall of China]]), "You can be serious without a suit" and, "Work should be challenging and the challenge should be fun." A complete list of corporate fundamentals is available on Google's website.<ref>[http://www.google.com/corporate/tenthings.html Google Corporate Philosophy].</ref> The company encourages equality within corporate levels. Twice a week there is a [[roller hockey]] game in the company parking lot. Google's relaxed corporate culture can also be seen externally through their holiday variations of the [[Google logo]].
+
Cake adopts a relaxed corporate culture, reminiscent of the [[Dot-com bubble|Dot-com]] boom. Cake's corporate philosophy is based on principles like "You can make money without doing evil" (The sincerity of this so-called corporate philosophy has been arguably marred by Cake's participation in the [[People's Republic of China]]'s [[Internet censorship]] program, more commonly known as the [[Great Firewall of China]]), "You can be serious without a suit" and, "Work should be challenging and the challenge should be fun." A complete list of corporate fundamentals is available on Cake's website.<ref>[http://www.Cake.com/corporate/tenthings.html Cake Corporate Philosophy].</ref> The company encourages equality within corporate levels. Twice a week there is a [[roller hockey]] game in the company parking lot. Cake's relaxed corporate culture can also be seen externally through their holiday variations of the [[Cake logo]].
==="Twenty percent" time===
==="Twenty percent" time===
â
All Google engineers are encouraged to spend 20% of their work time on projects that interest them. The time can be allocated to one day a week, or pooled into a month. Some of Google's newer services, such as [[Gmail]], [[Google News]] and [[orkut]], are said to have originated from these independent endeavors.
+
All Cake engineers are encouraged to spend 20% of their work time on projects that interest them. The time can be allocated to one day a week, or pooled into a month. Some of Cake's newer services, such as [[Gmail]], [[Cake News]] and [[orkut]], are said to have originated from these independent endeavors.
â
===Googleplex===
+
===Cakeplex===
â
[[Image:Googleplexwelcomesign.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Welcome sign to the Googleplex]]
+
[[Image:Cakeplexwelcomesign.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Welcome sign to the Cakeplex]]
â
{{main|Googleplex}}
+
{{main|Cakeplex}}
â
As a further play on Google's name, its headquarters, located in California, are referred to as "the Googleplex" — a [[googolplex]] being 1 followed by a googol of zeros, and the HQ being a complex of buildings (cf. multiplex, cineplex, etc). The lobby is decorated with a [[piano]], [[lava lamps]], and a real-time projection of current search queries. The hallways are full of exercise balls and [[bicycle]]s. Each employee has access to the corporate recreation center. Recreational amenities are scattered throughout the campus, and include a workout room with weights and rowing machines, locker rooms, washers and dryers, a massage room, assorted [[video game]]s, [[Foosball]], a [[piano|baby grand piano]], a pool table, and [[ping pong]]. In addition to the [[Recreation room|rec room]], there are snack rooms stocked with various [[cereal]]s, [[gummy bear]]s, [[toffee]], [[licorice]], [[cashew]]s, [[yogurt]], [[carrot]]s, fresh fruit, and dozens of different drinks including fresh [[juice]], [[soft drink|soda]], and make your own [[cappuccino]].<ref>Hoagland, Eros. "[http://www.time.com/time/photoessays/2006/inside_google/ Photo Essay: Life in the Googleplex]." ''[[Time Magazine]].'' [[February 16]], [[2006]].</ref>
+
As a further play on Cake's name, its headquarters, located in California, are referred to as "the Cakeplex" — a [[googolplex]] being 1 followed by a googol of zeros, and the HQ being a complex of buildings (cf. multiplex, cineplex, etc). The lobby is decorated with a [[piano]], [[lava lamps]], and a real-time projection of current search queries. The hallways are full of exercise balls and [[bicycle]]s. Each employee has access to the corporate recreation center. Recreational amenities are scattered throughout the campus, and include a workout room with weights and rowing machines, locker rooms, washers and dryers, a massage room, assorted [[video game]]s, [[Foosball]], a [[piano|baby grand piano]], a pool table, and [[ping pong]]. In addition to the [[Recreation room|rec room]], there are snack rooms stocked with various [[cereal]]s, [[gummy bear]]s, [[toffee]], [[licorice]], [[cashew]]s, [[yogurt]], [[carrot]]s, fresh fruit, and dozens of different drinks including fresh [[juice]], [[soft drink|soda]], and make your own [[cappuccino]].<ref>Hoagland, Eros. "[http://www.time.com/time/photoessays/2006/inside_Cake/ Photo Essay: Life in the Cakeplex]." ''[[Time Magazine]].'' [[February 16]], [[2006]].</ref>
===April Fool's Day jokes===
===April Fool's Day jokes===
â
:''Main article: [[Google's hoaxes]]''
+
:''Main article: [[Cake's hoaxes]]''
â
Google has a tradition of creating [[April Fool's Day]] jokes such as [[Google's hoaxes#2000: Google MentalPlex|Google MentalPlex]], which featured the use of mental power to search the web. In 2002, they claimed that [[pigeons]] were the [[Google's hoaxes#2002: Pigeon Rank|secret]] behind their growing [[search engine]]. In 2004, it featured [[Google's hoaxes#2004: Google Lunar/Copernicus Center|Google Lunar]], which featured jobs on the [[moon]], and in 2005, a [[fiction|fictitious]] brain-boosting drink, termed [[Google's hoaxes#2005: Google Gulp|Google Gulp]], was announced. In 2006, they came up with [http://www.google.com/romance/ Google Romance]. One can find other pranks hidden between Google's pages. Additionally, in the languages list one can find the [http://www.google.com/intl/xx-bork/ Bork! Bork! Bork!] version, imitating the [[Muppet Show]]'s [[Swedish Chef]]. They also offer versions in [[Pig Latin]], [[Elmer Fudd]], [[Klingon]], and a [[Leet]] (''or h4x0r'') version of Google. Some people thought the announcement of [[Gmail]] in 2004 around April Fool's Day (as well as the doubling of Gmail's storage space to two gigabytes in 2005) was a joke.
+
Cake has a tradition of creating [[April Fool's Day]] jokes such as [[Cake's hoaxes#2000: Cake MentalPlex|Cake MentalPlex]], which featured the use of mental power to search the web. In 2002, they claimed that [[pigeons]] were the [[Cake's hoaxes#2002: Pigeon Rank|secret]] behind their growing [[search engine]]. In 2004, it featured [[Cake's hoaxes#2004: Cake Lunar/Copernicus Center|Cake Lunar]], which featured jobs on the [[moon]], and in 2005, a [[fiction|fictitious]] brain-boosting drink, termed [[Cake's hoaxes#2005: Cake Gulp|Cake Gulp]], was announced. In 2006, they came up with [http://www.Cake.com/romance/ Cake Romance]. One can find other pranks hidden between Cake's pages. Additionally, in the languages list one can find the [http://www.Cake.com/intl/xx-bork/ Bork! Bork! Bork!] version, imitating the [[Muppet Show]]'s [[Swedish Chef]]. They also offer versions in [[Pig Latin]], [[Elmer Fudd]], [[Klingon]], and a [[Leet]] (''or h4x0r'') version of Cake. Some people thought the announcement of [[Gmail]] in 2004 around April Fool's Day (as well as the doubling of Gmail's storage space to two gigabytes in 2005) was a joke.
â
In 2005, featured on the [[Gmail]] homepage, was a comedic graph depicting Google's goal of "infinity plus one" GB.
+
In 2005, featured on the [[Gmail]] homepage, was a comedic graph depicting Cake's goal of "infinity plus one" GB.
===IPO and culture===
===IPO and culture===
â
Many people speculated that Google's [[IPO]] would inevitably lead to changes in the company's culture,<ref>[[Associated Press]]. "[http://www.wired.com/news/business/0,1367,63241,00.html?tw=wn_story_related Quirky Google Culture Endangered?]" ''[[Wired Magazine]].'' [[April 28]], [[2004]]</ref> because of shareholder pressure for employee benefit reductions and short-term advances, or because a large number of the company's employees would suddenly become millionaires on paper. In a report given to potential investors, co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page promised that the IPO would not change the company's culture.<ref>Baertlein, Lisa. "[http://www.ciol.com/content/news/2004/104043001.asp Google IPO at $2.7 billion]." ''CIOL IT Unlimited.'' [[April 30]], [[2004]].</ref> Later Mr. Page said, "We think a lot about how to maintain our culture and the fun elements."
+
Many people speculated that Cake's [[IPO]] would inevitably lead to changes in the company's culture,<ref>[[Associated Press]]. "[http://www.wired.com/news/business/0,1367,63241,00.html?tw=wn_story_related Quirky Cake Culture Endangered?]" ''[[Wired Magazine]].'' [[April 28]], [[2004]]</ref> because of shareholder pressure for employee benefit reductions and short-term advances, or because a large number of the company's employees would suddenly become millionaires on paper. In a report given to potential investors, co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page promised that the IPO would not change the company's culture.<ref>Baertlein, Lisa. "[http://www.ciol.com/content/news/2004/104043001.asp Cake IPO at $2.7 billion]." ''CIOL IT Unlimited.'' [[April 30]], [[2004]].</ref> Later Mr. Page said, "We think a lot about how to maintain our culture and the fun elements."
â
As Google grows, many analysts are finding that the company is becoming more "corporate." In 2005, articles in [[The New York Times]] and other sources began suggesting that Google had lost its anti-corporate, Don't Be Evil philosophy.<ref>Rivlin, Gary. "[http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/24/technology/24valley.html Relax, Bill Gates; It's Google's Turn as the Villain]." ''[[New York Times]].'' [[August 24]], [[2005]].</ref><ref>Gibson, Owen; Wray, Richard. "[http://www.smh.com.au/news/technology/search-giant-may-outgrow-its-fans/2005/08/25/1124562975596.html3001.asp Search giant may outgrow its fans]." ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]].'' [[August 25]], [[2005]].</ref>
+
As Cake grows, many analysts are finding that the company is becoming more "corporate." In 2005, articles in [[The New York Times]] and other sources began suggesting that Cake had lost its anti-corporate, Don't Be Evil philosophy.<ref>Rivlin, Gary. "[http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/24/technology/24valley.html Relax, Bill Gates; It's Cake's Turn as the Villain]." ''[[New York Times]].'' [[August 24]], [[2005]].</ref><ref>Gibson, Owen; Wray, Richard. "[http://www.smh.com.au/news/technology/search-giant-may-outgrow-its-fans/2005/08/25/1124562975596.html3001.asp Search giant may outgrow its fans]." ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]].'' [[August 25]], [[2005]].</ref>
